author: potuz
content: One issue with varying block times is that it becomes harder to estimate when the TTD will be hit.

author: pietjepuk
content: How so? Isn't the total difficulty increasing at a constant'ish rate per second, even with an ice age hitting?

author: potuz
content: Difficulty increases with the (inverse of) derivative of block times. If that stays constant I agree that modeling is not so bad. But if that changes at higher rates it becomes quite complicated. It's also a feature that we want, otherwise attacking the merge block would be easier

author: pietjepuk
content: I would say that, if the first order approximation is that the difficulty per unit of time stays the same (assuming constant hash rate but increasing block times), it's really not a big deal to have increasing block times. There are much larger uncertainties around the hash rate itself as the merge approaches imo

author: Deleted User
content: Do you have any proposals or it's simply "just be better and don't have bugs"? Do you want more testing instead of rushing it? But as you just said, Berlin wasn't rushed and there still was a bug.  You can never be sure something is bug-free. You test it until you fell it's enough, and then that's it. author: timbeiko
content:
Audits generally don‚Äôt help because a lot of the issues show up in weird edge cases based on multiple pieces of software interacting. 

Myself, Danny and several others are coordinating a lot of these efforts, with specific people owning specific items (e.g. Mikhail for specs, Pari for devnets, etc.). 

I personally communicate with several exchanges and blog posts around the actual upgrade will highlight what exchanges and infra providers should look for to pause/re-enable deposits and withdrawals. 

For apps on chain, the merge won‚Äôt cause any downtime and we already have a blog post on the EF blog explaining what changes they can expect. 

We have two bug bounties, are paying 2-3 external teams to help with testing, along with ad-hoc grants to especially engaged community contributors. 

I‚Äôve been spending a huge chunk of my time getting major infra and tooling providers to use Kiln (most of them publicly acknowledged in a twitter thread, unless they asked not to) and so far no one has reported a significant issue.
